extendedIngredients.name: ahi tuna steaks
extendedIngredients.original: 4 tuna steaks, about 1-1/2 inches thick (6 to 8 oz. each)
extendedIngredients.originalName: tuna steaks, about 1-1/2 inches thick each)

extendedIngredients.name: scallions
extendedIngredients.original: 1/4 cup thinly sliced scallions, both white and green parts (from about 4 scallions)
extendedIngredients.originalName: thinly sliced scallions, both white and green parts (from about 4 scallions)

title: Tuna With Roasted Jalapeño Tartar Sauce
summary: Tuna With Roasted Jalapeño Tartar Sauce might be just the main course you are searching for. Watching your figure? This gluten free, dairy free, whole 30, and pescatarian recipe has 471 calories, 40g of protein, and 33g of fat per serving. For $6.25 per serving, this recipe covers 33% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. This recipe serves 4. 1 person has made this recipe and would make it again. Head to the store and pick up vegetable oil, lime juice, cilantro, and a few other things to make it today. To use up the vegetable oil you could follow this main course with the Blueberry Coffee Cake #SundaySupper as a dessert. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 74%. This score is pretty good. Try Crab Cakes with Jalapeño-Lime Tartar Sauce, Tuna & Red Pepper Patties with Homemade Tartar Sauce, and Rollo De Salmon Ahumado Con Salsa Tartar Y Lentejas (Smoked Salmon Roll with Tartar Sauce and Lentils) for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Merlot, Pinot Noir, and rosé Wine are great choices for Tuna. Though fish is often paired with white wine, 'meatier' fish like tuna can absolutely go with red wine. A Rosé will also pair nicely, particularly if your tunan is prepared with ingredients better suited to a white wine. The Goldschmidt Vineyard Alexander Valley Chelsea Merlot with a 4.8 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 20 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Goldschmidt Vineyard Alexander Valley Chelsea Merlot
productMatches.description: Beautiful red raspberry, black cherry, and spice aromas. Full and round with plum, red currant, blackberry, and bay leaf flavors. The soft tannins give this wine a velvety smoothness and the chocolatey finish just goes on and on.

instructions: Set the jalapeos over a gas burner on medium-high heat or on a baking sheet under a broiler. Roast, turning occasionally until the skin chars all over, 6 to 7 minutes. Put the chiles in a paper bag or a bowl (cover with plastic) and let them steam.    Meanwhile, in a small bowl, whisk the mayonnaise, scallions, cilantro, lime juice and 2 Tbs. of the vegetable oil.    With a table knife, scrape the charred skin off the jalapeos. Discard the stems, cores, and seeds and chop the jalapeos finely. Stir about half of the jalapeos into the sauce, season to taste with salt, and add more jalapeos to tasteyou may not want to use them all. Chill until ready to serve.    In a small bowl, combine the cumin, 1-1/2 tsp. salt, and the pepper. Rub the mixture onto both sides of the tuna steaks. Heat the remaining 2 Tbs. vegetable oil in a 12-inch heavy-duty nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Add the tuna steaks and sear until browned on the first side, about 2 minutes. Flip and cook until browned on the second side, about 2 minutes more (the tuna will still be raw in the middle). Let the tuna rest for 2 minutes and with a very sharp knife, slice it crosswise into 1/4-inch-thick slices. Serve with the jalapeo sauce.                  nutrition information (per serving):        Calories                        (kcal):                      570, Fat                        (kcal):                      29, Fat Calories                        (g):                      250, Saturated Fat                        (g):                      4, Protein                        (g):                      72, Monounsaturated Fat                        (g):                      7, Carbohydrates                        (mg):                      3, Polyunsaturated Fat                        (mg):                      7, Sodium                        (g):                      630, Cholesterol                        (g):                      155, Fiber                        (g):                      1,                     Photo: Scott Phillips          Rate this Recipe and View Reviews

steps.step: Set the jalapeos over a gas burner on medium-high heat or on a baking sheet under a broiler. Roast, turning occasionally until the skin chars all over, 6 to 7 minutes.

Put the chiles in a paper bag or a bowl (cover with plastic) and let them steam.    Meanwhile, in a small bowl, whisk the mayonnaise, scallions, cilantro, lime juice and 2 Tbs. of the vegetable oil.    With a table knife, scrape the charred skin off the jalapeos. Discard the stems, cores, and seeds and chop the jalapeos finely. Stir about half of the jalapeos into the sauce, season to taste with salt, and add more jalapeos to tasteyou may not want to use them all. Chill until ready to serve.    In a small bowl, combine the cumin, 1-1/2 tsp. salt, and the pepper. Rub the mixture onto both sides of the tuna steaks.
Heat the remaining 2 Tbs. vegetable oil in a 12-inch heavy-duty nonstick skillet over medium-high heat.
Add the tuna steaks and sear until browned on the first side, about 2 minutes. Flip and cook until browned on the second side, about 2 minutes more (the tuna will still be raw in the middle).
Let the tuna rest for 2 minutes and with a very sharp knife, slice it crosswise into 1/4-inch-thick slices.
